cluster_relations.rel_desc: Mechanical and Metallurgical Failure and Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.object_entity_name: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: listed as peer damage mechanism categories in the same section

remarks: Relation reflects document-level grouping rather than a causal or hierarchical dependency; direction is arbitrary and used only to encode co-membership.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness and High Temperature Corrosion are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: co-listed as damage mechanism categories

remarks: Relation mainly encodes co-membership in the same list; not implying any causal or structural dependency between the mechanisms.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: High Temperature Corrosion and Environment Assisted Cracking are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Stress Corrosion and Environment Assisted Cracking Mechanisms

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: both are subsections under the same damage mechanisms section

remarks: Relation created to capture that both mechanisms are co-classified in the same document section; direction is arbitrary.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two entities are co-listed or grouped together as peer categories within the same document structure (e.g., same section or list), without implying causal, hierarchical, or compositional relationships.
args.justification: All three relations describe damage mechanism categories being presented as peer sections or co-listed categories within the same document section or list. This is purely a document-structure-based co-grouping with arbitrary direction and no implied causality or hierarchy, so they share the same canonical predicate 'grouped_with'.
args.remark: Predicate is intentionally symmetric and document-structure oriented; direction of the edge is not semantically meaningful.

args.justification: Each relation instance encodes that two damage mechanisms are co-classified or co-listed as peer categories in the same part of a document, which is best modeled as a document-level co-classification/grouping relation rather than a physical or causal relation.
args.remark: Use this class for relations that arise from document structure (peer sections, tables, lists) where entities are presented as coordinate categories.

args.justification: The semantics are that the entities are associated by co-occurrence and co-listing in the same document section, without a stronger physical, causal, or hierarchical meaning, which fits a broad ASSOCIATION group.
args.remark: These edges should be interpreted as weak associative links derived from document organization.
